http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Foul language refers to when a speech or other language is offensive, rude, or shocking
Illeism refers to the practice of referring to oneself in the third person
Metaphor refers to an expression that describes a person or object by referring to something that is considered to have similar characteristics to that person or object
Negative Nickname refers to an informal name for someone or something, usually based on your real name or your character, used to defame a political opponent

Opposition refers to the "black and white rhetoric", that creates and opposes two polarities

e.g. a Manichean and moralistic juxtaposition between the ‘‘good people’’ and the ‘‘evil elite’’
Paradox refers to a situation or statement that seems impossible or is difficult to understand because it contains two opposite facts or characteristics
Personification refers to the act of giving a human quality or characteristic to something which is not human
It refers to a meeting at which a person or organization makes a public statement and reporters can ask questions
Quotation refers to a phrase or short piece of writing taken from a longer work of literature, poetry, etc. or what someone else has said
Rhetorical question refers to a question, asked in order to make a statement, that does not expect an answer
Simile refers to the use of an expression comparing one thing with another, always including the words "as" or "like"
a short remark or piece of information published on Twitter

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: large and permanent human settlement.
It refers to a region that is identified as a distinct national entity in political geography
Immobile things or locations

group of people who come together to contest elections and hold power in the government. The party agrees on some proposed policies and programmes, with a view to promoting the collective good or furthering their supporters' interests.
A political figure
place or area with clustered or scattered buildings and a permanent human population (city, settlement, town, or village) referenced with geographic coordinates
It refers to a government minister who can take the position of acting prime minister when the prime minister is temporarily absent
Leader of a country or a division or part of a country, typically a republic, a democracy, or a dictatorship.
Head of an elected government; the principle minister of a sovereign or a state
A resource that acts or has the power to act
Relates an agent to a political role held in a certain period of time
An abstract idea or notion
A realization of a single work usually in a physical form.
A living or dead individual
It refers to any Region in a dimensional space that aims at representing time. It should be used when you want to talk about time as an object having some characteristics.
The Document class represents those things which are, broadly conceived, 'documents'.
A kind of Agent corresponding to social instititutions such as companies, societies etc.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Ontology (ASAP) is a rhetorics based ontology that expresses in a formal way the rhetorical discourse behind politician's speech acts.
Foul language refers to when a speech or other language is offensive, rude, or shocking
Illeism refers to the practice of referring to oneself in the third person
It refers to the speech given during the inuguration of an elected leader, informing the people of their intention as a leader
It refers to the lexical space occupied by a speech act
Metaphor refers to an expression that describes a person or object by referring to something that is considered to have similar characteristics to that person or object
Negative Nickname refers to an informal name for someone or something, usually based on your real name or your character, used to defame a political opponent

Opposition refers to the "black and white rhetoric", that creates and opposes two polarities

e.g. a Manichean and moralistic juxtaposition between the ‘‘good people’’ and the ‘‘evil elite’’
Paradox refers to a situation or statement that seems impossible or is difficult to understand because it contains two opposite facts or characteristics
Personification refers to the act of giving a human quality or characteristic to something which is not human
Polarity refers to the value
It represents the (reified) relationship between the agent holding a role and the role itself, within the boundaries of a particular timeinterval and applicable context for that role
It refers to a meeting at which a person or organization makes a public statement and reporters can ask questions
Quotation refers to a phrase or short piece of writing taken from a longer work of literature, poetry, etc. or what someone else has said
Rhetorical question refers to a question, asked in order to make a statement, that does not expect an answer
The class of some common tropes in political speech acts
The values connected to the outcome from sentiment analysis
Simile refers to the use of an expression comparing one thing with another, always including the words "as" or "like"
an utterance considered as an action, particularly with regard to its intention, purpose, or effect.
Subjectivity refers to the value
Refers to the most recurrent words present in a speech act
Topic refers to the retrieved topic of a single speech act
a short remark or piece of information published on Twitter
It relates the Speech Act with the place of deliverance
It relates the Speech Act with its Agent
It relates the Speech Act with the interval of time it has been delivered
It relates the speech act to the decimal value of the Dale Chall readability formula
It relates a speech act with its lexical complexity
It refers to the number of unique words present in a speech act
Refers to the decimal value of the polarity related to a specific speech act
The words able to describe the semantic space of a toic
This property relates a literary text that contains a rhetorical figure.
It relates the sentiment value with its speech act
It relates the speech act to che subjectivity of the text
Refers to the decimal value of the subjectivity related to a specific speech act
It refers to the ten most recurrent couples of words of a speech act
It refers to the ten most recurrent triples of words of a speech act
It refers to the ten most recurrent words of a speech act
It relates a speech act with its top words
It relates a speech act with its topic
relates the agent of delivery of a speech act to a speech act
This property relates a rhetorical figure with a particular speech act in which it is present.
relates a political role in time to the agent that holds or has held it
Relates the lexical complexity of a speech act to the speech act
relates the place of delivery of a speech act to a speech act
It relates a topic to the speech act in which it is present
Relates one elment to another
Relates the sentiment of a speech act to the speech act
Relates the subjectivity of a speech act to the speech act
relates the time of delivery of a speech act to a speech act
Relates a top word in a speech act to the speech act
one element is related to another
Relates a concept to a text that includes its textual string reference
